pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 356, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2 (P2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 399]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 670, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve \(y = \ln (5x + 1)\) at the point where \(x = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 120, 96, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 918, 140]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(|2x - 3| \leqslant |3x|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 166, 96, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 510, 186]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(2\ln (x + 3) - \ln x = \ln (2x - 2).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 212, 96, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 212, 425, 231]]<|/det|>
(i) Express \(\cos^2 x\) in terms of \(\cos 2x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 244, 151, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 244, 295, 262]]<|/det|>
Hence show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 263, 660, 303]]<|/det|>
\[\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{6}\pi}(\cos^{2}x + \sin 2x)\mathrm{d}x = \frac{1}{8}\sqrt{3} +\frac{1}{12}\pi +\frac{1}{4}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 274, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 339, 96, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 338, 836, 357]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(5\sec^{2}2\theta = \tan 2\theta +9\), giving all solutions in the interval \(0^{\circ}\leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 96, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 384, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
(i) The polynomial \(x^{4} + ax^{3} - x^{2} + bx + 2\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, is denoted by \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). It is given that \((x - 1)\) and \((x + 2)\) are factors of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\). Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 402, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 432, 151, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 432, 836, 451]]<|/det|>
When \(a\) and \(b\) have these values, find the quotient when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \(x^{2} + x - 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 477, 96, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 489, 761, 693]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 715, 828, 735]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = (x - 4)\mathrm{e}^{\frac{1}{2}x}\). The curve has a gradient of 3 at the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 747, 153, 766]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 747, 584, 766]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) satisfies the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 774, 556, 797]]<|/det|>
\[x = 2 + 6\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 777, 920, 796]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 816, 153, 834]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 816, 740, 834]]<|/det|>
Verify that the equation in part (i) has a root between \(x = 3.1\) and \(x = 3.3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 816, 920, 834]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 851, 151, 870]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 851, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula \(x_{n + 1} = 2 + 6\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x_{n}}\) to determine this root correct to 2 decimal places. Give the result of each iteration to 4 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 887]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 510, 94]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(2x^{2} - 3x - 3y + y^{2} = 6.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 108, 153, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 351, 131]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{4x - 3}{3 - 2y}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 147, 153, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 146, 787, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the two points on the curve at which the gradient is \(-1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 147, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
